QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Hill representing the Prime Minister. Are you aware that on the radio program PM last night the President of the Australian Bar Association, Mr Chris Pullen, expressed concern about both your government's as well as Premier Borbidge's attacks on the High Court which he described `as unprecedented in the last 20 to 30 years'? Are you also aware that on the same program the Attorney-General said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . if courts generally are slow if making decisions, that's a proper subject for comment. . . But when you get down to an individual case, it comes very close to making a criticism on a personal ground of the court, of individual members of the court, and that's not appropriate.
Is it not true Deputy Prime Minister Fischer criticised the court saying:
I am frustrated and angered by the delay in handing down of the decision by the High Court of Australia with regard to the Wik case.

Is it not true that Mr Borbidge described Sir Gerard Brennan's defence of the court as `pathetic and lamentable'? Do you still disclaim, as you did yesterday, any knowledge of any personal attacks on the High Court? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I do. I think it is reasonable to be frustrated about delays in important cases that have an effect upon so many Australians. Beyond that, of course, it is reasonable to assess the reasons for such delay and the court might have arguments on its side in that regard. I am not sure, but I certainly see it as legitimate for the Deputy Prime Minister to say that he and his constituents are frustrated by important cases taking so long to be decided.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Surely the minister must be aware of Premier Borbidge's comments on the High Court when he called them a `bunch of dills' and he likened them to `kings and queens of old' and Mr Fischer's comment when he called one of Justice Kirby's statements `awful'? When will someone from your government have the guts to come to the defence of the High Court or are you waiting for the results on a poll on the issue to decide which way you are going?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think it is a good idea for the Labor Party to talk about polls today. They may well have noted that we are now polling better than we did at the election. Twelve months later, after taking a lot of hard decisions to address the economic mess that we inherited from you lot—$8,000 million of deficit—we take those hard decisions and our poll actually rises.

ANSWER.PARA: Apart from the issue of our rising polls, yes, as I said to you yesterday, we accept a responsibility to ensure that the public maintains confidence in the High Court and confidence in our judicial system. It is an important part of our democracy and we will accept responsibility, but we certainly have the right to say we disagree with particular judgments. There is nothing new in that and there is nothing wrong with that. We have certainly got to right to say we are frustrated because judgments are taking so long to be put down. Beyond that, I do not think I have anything else to add.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is to the Minister for the Environment. I refer the minister to the Prime Minister's release yesterday of the oceans policy discussion paper and his announcement of new initiatives to complement the policy development. What had been the reaction to the release of the discussion paper and to the government's funding commitments which accompany it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the senator for that very important question. It reminds me, now that Senator Bolkus has got me focused on polls, that the Sydney Morning Herald did a poll on the community's assessment of this government's environmental management. I am pleased to advise you that the community gave us a 70 per cent rating, which is not bad. Of course what it means is that the community actually accepts that attempting to support development and job growth consistent with sound economic management is the way that the community would wish to see its government go.

ANSWER.PARA: But yesterday, consistent with that philosophy again, the Prime Minister took another step towards the government's commitment of producing an integrated oceans policy for Australia. We will be one of the very few countries in the world that has actually tackled that challenge, partly because it is so difficult and partly because the concentration in the past has been on the land mass.

However, it is worth remembering that our ocean responsibilities—the extended economic zone—now cover something like twice the size of our land mass, and with it comes new economic opportunities together with new environmental responsibilities. What this government has said—consistent again with an election promise—is that we will produce an oceans policy for the first time in the history of Australia that addresses that enormous challenge.

What we did yesterday was to issue a discussion paper which will now be out in the community for a couple of months. We look forward to community input on it. We are a government the engages the community in these processes. From that we will be producing options papers which we will put back to the community later this year. Out of that, by next year when we get to the international year of oceans, we should be in a position to deliver on our promise in full and that is produce an integrated oceans policy for Australia. The sorts of issues that we are looking at in this challenge are the issues of the marine environment, issues of pollution, issues of industry development, our international relations, indigenous issues and so they go on.

They are challenging; they are difficult. There is no doubt about that. But, again, it is our responsibility to work out how we can maximise our economic opportunity from the oceans whilst at the same time preserve that unique environment. We still do not know enough about it. Therefore, we need more science. We need a better information base. You would expect that we would be cautious. We do not want to make the same mistakes in relation to oceans that we have made in relation to our land mass. We want to learn from the mistakes of the past.

Labor knocked this; they could not see any relevance, but it was heartening to see community interest groups such as the World Wide Fund for Nature coming out and warmly welcoming our approach. The Australian Marine Conservation Society also welcomed the release of the paper and wanted to be involved in its further development. That is a good sign.

TALK.START.PARA: —They supported the budget cuts to the program?

—They support this policy absolutely. They are frustrated that after 13 years Labor did not even attempt to develop an oceans policy for this country. Again, it is the Howard government going first, leading, providing the example, involving the community in the process for a good environmental outcome and a good economic outcome. That is what the people of Australia want.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister aware of criticism of Australia for not pursuing marine issues through APEC? How does the minister respond to that? What are the government's plans in relation to further marine issues?

—The only criticism I heard was from the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, who failed to understand that there was an APEC environment ministers' conference last year in the Philippines in which the exact issue I have been talking about—protecting the marine environment within the Asia Pacific region—was regarded as one of the three most vital issues facing this community. We took that up. We participated in that debate. It has been taken on by Canada, which, as the leader of APEC for this year, will be part of that process also. Regrettably, I have heard of the criticism, but it was by somebody who was unaware of the leadership that Australia is playing in this area.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, what action will you be taking to protect the government's budget cuts of $214 million following the tightening of the Austudy actual means test? Hasn't it now been six days since you were made aware of the Department of Social Security's legal advice that highlights the lack of substantive legislative provision of the Austudy actual means test regulations? Will you now concede that these regulations will not withstand `a half‐hearted legal challenge'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much for that question, Senator Carr. As with a lot of recent reporting on this subject, there is a serious inaccuracy contained within your question. First, the so-called legal opinion that I think you are referring to is not considered legal advice; rather, a draft working paper circulated by a relatively junior officer in the Department of Social Security without any sort of departmental approval. That is, it is one person's opinion—and not the senior person's with respect to that matter.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, it is important to understand that the legal basis of the AMT on which this government has not and will not back down remains that established by Labor. The test is as good as the legal basis your previous government gave it. The key provisions of the regulations established by Labor were the estimation of actual means by reference to the total expenditure and savings of the applicants. That has not changed.

The major change which I approved in July last year was the use of self‐assessment in place of imputation. That did not require a change in regulations at all. It was purely a question of administrative process and customer service. The subsequent use by departmental officers of a form of imputation as a means of assessment rather than as a compliance check was a departure from the process that I approved in July last year. It is a matter that I take seriously. As you know, from having been at the estimates, the matter is currently under investigation in the department.

BREAK.PARA: I note, Senator Carr, that you seem to be pleased that the test Labor established is now under question. However, we would be interested to know what you think of and whether you agree with a further observation in the paper: that is, that the bulk of the people affected by the actual means test are likely to be those people who have the legal resources available to challenge the regime. In other words, do you agree that an actual means test is necessary? Do you agree that it is targeted at people with real means? Because you need plenty of dough to challenge a government these days and that has been the case for some time

In other words, the author of the paper believes that the test has successfully identified the people it was intended to catch—those who legally but artificially lower their incomes. If you do think that we need such a test, then you ought to say so. If you don't, you equally ought to come out and say so.

You must understand, Senator Carr, that the actual means test was established by your government. It has been left in place by our government. There were some changes that we made. The essential changes that related to the difficulties in the early part of the year were not in conformity with the brief that I signed off in July. You, therefore, have very substantial responsibility should there be a problem. I remind you in conclusion that this was an independent note written by a relatively junior officer in the department and, in that sense, it is not the Department of Social Security's view.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, do I take it from your answer that you do concede there are legal problems with the regulations? Further, do you recall that at the EET estimates you said that you were considering tabling your department's legal advice on the Austudy regulations of February 1997? Will you now table that advice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —As you understand, Senator Carr, that advice relates to a separate matter in relation to the AMT. Let us have no confusion that we are talking about one and the same piece of advice. In one sense we are talking about legal advice = that is the advice that I was referring to in the estimates. In another sense, we are talking about the view of a relatively junior officer in the Department of Social Security.

ANSWER.PARA: Given that you have put so much credence on the view of the junior officer in the DSS—which I assume you do since you have bothered to take up a question with it—and since that indicates that the people affected by the actual means test are people with real means who might challenge the government, I have to think very seriously about whether I would prejudice the Commonwealth's position and release that advice to you. I am afraid, by giving such emphasis to the junior officer's view, you have led me to pretty well conclude that the answer to that question is no.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw to the attention of honourable senators the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from Kenya, led by the Deputy Speaker of the National Assembly, Mr Godana. It gives me great pleasure to welcome you here to the Senate. I trust that your visit will be both enjoyable and informative.
— Hear, hear!

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. I ask the minister a question that concerns another very important election commitment which has been honoured by this coalition government. I refer to the previous Labor government's failure to introduce an up‐to‐date and workable moral rights copyright regime which recognises the rights of artists. What progress has the government made in delivering its promise to legislate for very long overdue copyright reform in this area which provides fair and adequate protection for artists?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —Moral rights for artists is a very important issue. It is a classic example of another area where Labor talked big but did virtually nothing.
—Too hard!

—It was in the too hard basket for years. You might remember what Mr Keating had to say when he was crying in his cups when he thought he had lost the 1993 election. He was out there saying, `What have we done for the arts? Everyone says that we are for the arts, but what have we done? Not much and it is about time we did something for them.' He then proceeded to come up with Creative Nation after innumerable adjournments and delays and ministers being trumped. But they could never bite the bullet on moral rights. It was all too hard. It left the arts community with a feeling of great disillusionment because there were some who were misguided enough to think that the Keating government was fair dinkum.
—They actually voted for us, not you.

—By the time we got to the election last year, Senator Cook, they were very much disillusioned with what had actually been put on the table. That is why it is very important that this government is now in a position to announce that we are able to implement our pre-election commitment. We have always said that we regard copyright reform as a major area. In the instance of moral rights, we are now able to announce that the copyright bill, which will be introduced into the parliament shortly, will contain a very good regime to implement our international obligations under the Berne convention. We are going down the path that has been followed by a number of other countries, including the United States, New Zealand, the United Kingdom, France and Germany.

ANSWER.PARA: What we are doing essentially is recognising that artists—that is a fairly broad category; those who are creators of product in the area of cultural activity—are entitled to be identified as the authors of those works. They are entitled to protection against false attribution and they also have a right of integrity to complain where there is degradation or interference with their works. A classic example of that would be Aboriginal artists who have been left high and dry for very many years in this area. For example, if an Aboriginal artist has produced a painting which is then adapted to a T-shirt or a tea towel, that can very much degrade the whole cultural and spiritual significance of the original work. Until a moral rights regime is in place, there is simply nothing that they can do about it. That is one of the areas that has been crying out for reform and where this government has been prepared to take that action.

Under these reforms, authors, artists and film makers, both producers and directors, will have the right to assert a moral right, not an economic right, but one that can be protected in a court of law if necessary by way of injunction. It will be balanced against the reasonableness test so that there will be the opportunity to reflect industry standards and concerns to ensure that you simply cannot hold up the reproduction of a work by a trivial claim. But the principle is a very important one—that is, those who do have a right ought to be able to assert it and ought to be able to be recognised as having that right.

It does not apply to all elements of the arts. Indeed, the Film Finance Commission was arguing against a right to film producers and directors. We do not share that view. But we certainly take the view that the right that attaches to a script writer should not then be allowed to follow through in the process. Ultimately, these rights will be able to be waived. They will apply for 50 years in accordance with normal practice. Those rights will be very distinct from the economic rights which exist in a copyright work.

It is a very significant and long overdue reform, one which this government is delighted to be able to say it is delivering in spades to the arts community, which has been pressing for these reforms. It is very much an indication that we are serious and Labor was not. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Can the minister tell the chamber the reaction of artists to this proposed bill.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ferris would be aware that there has been a lot of concern in the arts community that these reforms, which some people would go around saying they supported in principle, had never actually been put in place and practice. I think you will find that overwhelmingly there will be a sigh of relief and there will be a recognition that this government has been serious in addressing those concerns and they will feel much more heartened in their negotiations. They will know that they cannot simply be pushed aside or effectively precluded from taking legal action because of cost and the risks associated with the current regime. For the first time they will have an explicit statutory right which will provide the basis for legal action and injunctions to restrain behaviour, enabling them to assert their rights in the best and most appropriate forum. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Do you recall your departmental secretary confirming at last week's estimates hearings that your department had been aware since 11 November last year of the serious legal questions hanging over the current Austudy actual means test regulations? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

—Senator Vanstone, your remarks should be addressed through the chair, not directly to any senator, but the question was asked by Senator Hogg.

—I do apologise, Madam President. I just feel so deeply for Senator Carr that he feels he needs to be so gruff and engage in such bluster and blunder and interrupt an answer being given to a question asked by one of his colleagues. I do accept your point, Madam President. I will try and restrain myself.

ANSWER.PARA: If Senator Hogg had been listening, he would have understood that this really is—I think it is fair to describe it in this way—a personal opinion of a relatively junior officer, passed to an officer in my department without any sort of formal departmental approval. It is not—

TALK.START.PARA: —It was commissioned!
—Senator Carr, you are free to take note of the answer at a later hour.
—I certainly will.

—On that basis, Senator Hogg, I just invite you to go over the Hansard for the answer I gave to Senator Carr. I will leave it at that and let other people, who perhaps were listening, get on with questions.

—I do not think the minister understood the question, but I will proceed with the supplementary question. At estimates last week you also undertook to seek further advice on the validity of the foundations of the Austudy actual means test. Have you done so and will you table that advice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have any further advice yet. I did say that I would seek further advice. It would be an enormous embarrassment, of course, to the previous government if you had set up an actual means test which had an inappropriate legal basis, but it would be a huge inconvenience to everybody else—not least, people affected by such a test. Of course, if there were a problem I would check it out. That is a very sensible thing to do. Have I thus far received that advice? No.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment. While welcoming the move towards a national oceans policy, I refer to the Prime Minister's statement at the launch yesterday. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . there will be some very special areas of outstanding environmental value that should never be disturbed. We will protect them accordingly.

I ask: are you aware that in November last year a petroleum exploration permit was granted for Shark Bay in Western Australia, that this is a world heritage listed area and that it is renowned for its outstanding environmental value? Is it true that the exploration permit is over a substantial part of the waters of the Shark Bay world heritage area and will allow construction of two exploration wells? What assessment was done by the Commonwealth for this proposal?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not recall that permit.
—You don't recall much, do you?

—I recall a fair bit, but I do not recall that permit. I know of other economic activities that take place in Shark Bay, such as pearling operations and the like. It is not a total exclusion zone, if that is the right expression.
—It's not.
—No, it's not. Have you ever been there?
—As a matter of fact—

—You were the one who actually failed in your negotiations with Western Australia on Shark Bay—couldn't set up the community consultative committee, if I recall. But I will research the issue and come back to you and give you a more authoritative answer, Senator.

—Thank you, Minister. As it is a world heritage area and as you are responsible for it under the World Heritage Act, if you find it is correct that we are looking at exploration permits will you move to stop any oil exploration in Shark Bay? I remind you of what you said yesterday about stopping any exploration on the Great Barrier Reef. Can we not compare those two areas for significance?

—That is the question: what activities are consistent with the environment values we are seeking to protect or conserve? That is the test we apply. In relation to the Barrier Reef, we have decided that certain economic activities in a regulated way are consistent, such as fishing and tourism, but that mining is not. So that would be the test I would apply and which I would like to see others apply also to Shark Bay. I have already said to you that there are some economic activities in Shark Bay that are said to be consistent with the conservation values. But let me find out exactly what permit has been given, the basis for it and whether in fact it did come to our attention. I think I might be able to then give you a more useful answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Can you assure the Senate that your so-called parental means test is not just another name for Senator Vanstone's failed modified Austudy actual means test? Furthermore, have you taken full account of your legal branch's critique of Senator Vanstone's test in developing the parental means test? Will the parental means test be applied only to recipients of your proposed new youth allowance, as Senator Vanstone seemed to be implying at estimates, or is it being considered for application to all social security recipients?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity that Senator Murphy has not listened to the answers on this subject before. The situation is that, as I answered I think Senator O'Brien last week, when I got this job I discovered that the Labor Party that had administered this portfolio for 13 years had not made any really serious effort to try to make sure that social security entitlements went to those who were genuinely needy. They claimed these sorts of things, but in fact there were very real concerns—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Faulkner interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Newman has the call.

—We had some complaints yesterday about sledging, Madam President; I hope that we will not get any more of that today. Senator Murphy, DEETYA in fact had a means test, which I was told about when I got this job, which actually was designed to deal with people who have some affluence. The intention was, as you know, to—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Faulkner interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner, please desist.
—You should know, Senator Murphy, that that means test was in DEETYA, because it was your government that introduced it. Quite properly, they introduced it—
—You modified it.

—Surely we should share the same goal of not having Austudy or social security benefits—two portfolios—going to people who are not genuinely entitled. Therefore, I asked about the actual means test, which was the one that was applied in DEETYA, and concerns were expressed to me. I have said this before, but I will repeat it in case you did not take it in. The situation is that my departmental officers expressed some concerns about the way it was being administered.
—Some concerns!
—Senator Carr, cease interjecting.

—You have heard here Senator Vanstone talk to you about a document that was referred to in the Senate estimates committee for DEETYA. That was, I am told, an internal working document. It was nothing to do with a briefing to the minister; it was nothing that I asked for. I had had briefings, as I said last week, months and months before. I had put out a press release in September, saying that in July I had asked for work to be done in my department to make sure that people of affluence were not able to access social security entitlements.

ANSWER.PARA: That does not mean that Social Security is doing an actual means test. It means that it is looking at why Social Security has not, under the previous 13 years of management, been able to make sure that these people are not getting benefits that they are not entitled to.

I understand that that document that Senator Vanstone has been answering questions about was produced as a working document in my department. I understand that it was handed on 11 November to an officer in the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs in a spirit of cooperation, if you like. That was the purpose of the whole exercise—that, if these two departments work effectively together, we have an opportunity to achieve the goal of not having either Austudy or social security benefits going to people who are not entitled to them.

The critique that you referred to was not a legal opinion. It was a working document about the social security department's views on the administration and the implementation of the actual means test as introduced by your government. It was nothing do with any subsequent changes to the actual means test, I understand. I did not ask for the paper; it was not provided to me; nor was I briefed upon it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. Minister, given that statement and given the significant stuff‐up that surrounded the application of the Austudy actual means test, can you assure potential recipients of your proposed youth allowance that they will not be worse off under your new regime?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The youth allowance has not been determined by the government as yet. It is a matter before cabinet. When cabinet has decided the various components of it, it will be announced. Let me make it quite clear, however, that the last budget announced that we would move to a common youth payment. That was well received by most of the advocacy groups, including ACOSS, and they have been consulted widely by both DEETYA and the Department of Social Security in the intervening months.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of that wide-ranging consultation, we have listened to the concerns of those groups. Therefore, the government has before it a number of proposals, which I am not prepared to discuss here until cabinet has made a decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is addressed to the minister representing the minister for transport, Senator Alston. Can the minister categorically confirm or deny that any planning or consultancy work has been commissioned or is being planned or carried out relating to the feasibility or development of a fourth runway at Kingsford Smith Airport? If so, what are the details? Is the minister aware that the Federal Airports Corporation is proposing $2 billion worth of development and construction at the airport on top of the Rockdale project A, as flagged in today's Sydney Morning Herald ? This proposed development will massively increase the capacity at the airport. Will there be an EIS carried out into these proposed developments? Will they receive government approval without an EIS? What does the government know about the potential serious impacts on both the environment and the health and welfare of residents of the city of Sydney?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not have any plans for a fourth runway at Kingsford Smith. As I understand it, proponents of this idea briefed members of parliament last year on various permutations and combinations involving a floating, stilt based or solid earth structure—all of which apparently depended upon the level of siltation that might have been thought appropriate in Botany Bay.

BREAK.PARA: But the fact is that the government has never had any plans to go down that path. We have capped movements at Kingsford Smith Airport at 80 movements an hour and we have said, clearly, that we will cater for growth in aircraft movements by developing a second major airport for Sydney.

The article to which Senator Brown refers in the Sydney Morning Herald relates to a proposal on Cooks River, which is, as I understand it, opposite the international terminal at Kingsford Smith. That report presumably results from a briefing by the Federal Airports Corporation, who initiated a meeting between an architectural firm, a planning group and the Rockdale council, to discuss planning issues. Rockdale council has expressed an interest in a tourism and conference development at the airport and, as a result of that interest, a concept document is being worked up by the council. That, presumably, is the basis for the article in today's paper.

The feasibility study is currently being developed for the council, but it is not at a stage where an EIS has been scheduled. The FAC has no direct stake in the proposal. The chief proponent of the development is the Rockdale city council. The federal government has not given its support to the proposal.

It is important to note that the proposal has no impact on aircraft operations at Sydney airport. It will not increase the airport's capacity and it will not increase aircraft noise. The proposal depends on private capital. If it does go ahead, it will not divert resources or the government's attention from the development of the second Sydney airport. These two issues are not related and they should not be seen in any context relating to any increase in aircraft noise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Firstly, will the minister require an environmental impact assessment of the $2 billion worth of proposed developments at Kingsford Smith Airport, leaving aside the Rockdale project A? Secondly, will he rule out government support for a fourth runway proposal at the Kingsford Smith Airport?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I had made it clear that the government does not have any plans for a fourth runway.
—Do you rule it out?
—I am simply saying that. No-one has put any proposal forward. We have no intention of going down that path and I have explained that we remain firmly committed to the development of a second runway.
—But do you rule it out?

—I have made that clear. We have no intention of going down that path. It has never been suggested. We have explored a number of other possible areas, but it is simply not on the agenda. I do not think anyone has even suggested that it should be. The government certainly never contemplated it for a moment. The Rockdale proposal is one that has not yet reached a stage where there could be an EIS; but, again, that is not a matter for us. PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned shows that only one group have been excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) where such group has performed honourable overseas `active service'. That group being members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 which were excluded under `Operational Service' at Section 6. (1)(e)(ii) of the Act.

The various claims made in Statements to the House and the Senate and the contents of correspondence from various Ministers to maintain the exclusion are answered as follows, the answers are from documents obtained under FIO and from public record:

(i) `They were never allotted for operational service', (contained in a letter from the Hon. Con Sciacca Minister for Defence Science and Personnel 1995). A letter from the Secretary Department of the Navy to Treasury dated 11 November 1955 stated `the date that the Navy were allotted for operational service was 1 July 1955'.

(ii) `Members of the RAN were only doing the duty for which they had enlisted', (October 1956 The Hon. Dr Cameron representing the Minister for Repatriation in the Senate). This applies to all Service personnel everywhere.

(iii) `They were in no danger', (November 1956 The Hon. Dr Cameron representing the Minister for Repatriation in the Senate). They shared the same danger as all other Australian Service personnel serving in Malaya at the time.

(iv) `They were not on Special Overseas Service', (in a letter from the office of The Hon. Bronwyn Bishop Minister for Defence Industry Science and Personnel to Mrs Williams of Adelaide dated October 1996). Requirement for Special Overseas Service was introduced in 1962 without retrospective conditions, therefore has no relevance to events of 1960.

(v) `They were not on Active Service', (in a letter from the office of The Hon. Bronwyn Bishop Minister for Defence Industry Science and Personnel dated October 1996). It is now, as it was then, that Service Personnel had to comply with one of three requirements for Active Service, this group complied with two, or twice as many as is needed. The one that they did not comply with was, `is in military occupation of a foreign country'.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate should remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act, thereby giving the Australian sailors involved comparative recognition with the Army and RAAF personnel that served at the same time, and all other Australians who have served their Country on active service overseas.

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are the only Australians to be deliberately excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) for honourable `active service'. Australian Archives records show that the only reason for the exclusion was to save money. Members of the Australian Army and Air Force serving in Malaya were not excluded, and the costs associated with the land forces was one of the main reasons for the exclusion of the Navy. An injustice was done which later events have compounded.

There are two forms of benefits for ex‐servicemen, disability pensions for war caused disabilities (denied the sailors referred to but introduced in 1972 for `Defence Service' within Australia) and Service Pensions. Allied veterans of 55 nations involved in conflicts with Australian forces until the end of the Vietnam War can have qualifying eligibility Service Pensions under the Act. Service by 5 countries in Vietnam was recognised after RAN service in Malaya was excluded. The Department of Veterans' Affairs confirms that 686 ex‐members of the South Vietnamese Armed Forces are in receipt of Australian Service Pensions; 571 on married rate and 115 on single rate. In effect 1,257 Service Pensions, denied to ex‐members of the RAN, are being paid for serving alongside Australians in Vietnam.
It is claimed that:

(a) Naval personnel were engaged on operational duties that applied to all other Australian service personnel serving overseas on `active service'. They bombarded enemy positions in Malaya and secretly intercepted enemy communications;

(b) Naval personnel were subject to similar dangers as all other Australian service personnel serving in Malaya and there were RAN casualties, none of which appear on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial;

(c) the Royal Australian Navy was `allotted' for operational service from 1st July 1955 and this is documented in Navy Office Minute No. 011448 of 11 November 1955, signed by the Secretary to the Department of the Navy. The RAN was then apparently `unallotted' secretly to enable the excluding legislation to be introduced;

(d) the Department of Veterans' Affairs has said it can find no written reason(s) for the RAN exclusion in the Act. In two independent Federal Court cases (Davis WA G130 of 1989 and Doessel Qld G62 of 1990) the courts found the two ex‐members of the RAN who served in Malaya and who had, at that time, claims before the Department of Veterans' Affairs for benefits, had their claims accepted. Eight weeks after the Doessel decision the Act was amended to require allotment to have been by written instrument. In parliament, it was claimed the amendment was necessary to restore the intended purpose of the exclusion, reasons for which can not, allegedly, be found.

(e) Naval personnel were not, as claimed, bound by the `Special Overseas Service' requirements, introduced in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962. This act became law some two years after the war in Malaya ended;

(f) as Australian citizens serving with the Royal Australian Navy they complied with three of the four requirements for `active service'. The fourth, for `military occupation of a foreign country' did not apply to Malaya.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act thereby restoring justice and recognition of honourable `active service' with the Royal Australian Navy in direct support of British and Malayan forces during the Malayan Emergency, between 1955 and 1960.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that general business notice of motion No. 475, standing in my name, be taken as formal.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Faulkner moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 475.

This is a matter of urgency. This is something that the Senate needs to deal with today. We have a situation where a constitutional vandal in Queensland, the Premier of Queensland, Mr Borbidge—right in the Bjelke‐Petersen mould—has publicly debauched the constitution and, I might say, has done so in the true tradition of the Queensland Nationals.

Mr Borbidge has, over the past couple of days, indicated, firstly, that Senator Colston may resign; and, secondly, that if he does, he would consider filling that vacancy with an Independent or, on the other hand, he may consider delaying an appointment, appointing someone who does not have the confidence of the Australian Labor Party in Queensland or reappointing Senator Colston. That is what the Premier of Queensland has said.

It is urgent that the Senate today deal with this issue. Do not fall for this trick of declaring it formal, because these people, the coalition government, are going to oppose this motion. We have a situation where, if there is a vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Colston, clearly, under the spirit and the letter of section 15 of Australia's constitution, the vacancy in the position must be filled by a candidate who is endorsed by and has the confidence of the Australian Labor Party in Queensland.

We have a situation where Senator Colston, when he was elected to this place, was elected by the Labor voters in Queensland. It is Labor voters in Queensland who had faith and confidence in Senator Colston and it is the Labor voters in Queensland who have had demonstrated to them that Senator Colston was not worthy of that confidence or loyalty. It is Senator Colston who has shown absolute treachery to the party to which he belonged and to the Labor voters who selected him to represent them and the Australian Labor Party in this parliament.

This is something which the federal government can deal with. This is something that is within Mr Howard's and Senator Hill's gift and capacity to deal with. If Senator Colston resigns, then the coalition government can pair that vacancy if Mr Borbidge decides to rip up the constitution. We simply do not accept the word of the Liberals or the federal government on this. We will not accept their word on this.

Labor, of course, always keeps its word, always honours the conventions of this place and always honours the procedures of this place. But I am afraid that our impeccable standards are not reflected on the other side of the chamber. We will not accept your word. We want your commitment in black and white to this principle of pairing this vacancy. We want it in black and white.

BREAK.PARA: We want you to put your money where your mouth is on this issue. It is an open and shut case and it is within the gift of this government to demonstrate that they have the same commitment as the Australian Labor Party to protecting the constitution and to ensuring that the spirit and the letter of the Australian constitution is honoured. There is only one way to do that and that is to vote for this suspension of standing orders, vote for the motion before the Senate and do it now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is one of the grubbiest little exercises I have experienced in 15 years in this place. All this is about is internal Labor Party politics. There was no disguise in the words of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) at all. What did he say? He said that the Labor Party regards Senator Colston as treacherous. That is what this motion is all about: punishment for Senator Colston for deciding that he would exercise a democratic right and leave the Australian Labor Party. Since the day Senator Colston made that decision, the Australian Labor Party have hounded him in a way that no other individual in Australian politics has experienced.
—And so we should.

—Senator Ray acknowledges it. `And so we should,' says Senator Ray. They will hound him until they bring him down. That is why this is disgraceful. It has nothing to do with provisions of the constitution at all. It has got even less to do with issues of urgency or otherwise in this chamber. How can it possibly be urgent that this is voted upon today? How can it possibly be implemented today?
—There's not even a vacancy.

—There is no vacancy. But within the motivation for this motion you find the true story. The true story is that the Australian Labor Party has found Senator Colston, without trial, guilty of offences that justify his resignation.
—Address yourself to the motion. What's wrong with the motion?

—I am telling you. That is what it is all about. If you say it often enough—that Senator Colston has rorted, or Senator Colston has breached this and breached that; that Senator Colston must go—you start creating the impression that it is a reality. But he has not even been charged. He has not even been tried. But the Australian Labor Party has found him guilty.

SPEECH.PARA: That is why this grubby little exercise is disgraceful. There has been no charge and no trial; but you find him guilty, hound him and use every bit of privilege that is open to you within this parliament to drive him out, as punishment for leaving the Australian Labor Party, because you regard that as treacherous. That is why this exercise is such a disgrace.

What has it got to do with section 15 of the constitution? Absolutely nothing. It is not a motion about section 15 of the constitution. In any event, we are on the record as saying—I said it in question time yesterday—that section 15 is clear and unambiguous. We accept the 1977 amendments. We accept that, when there is a casual vacancy, a state government has to appoint someone from the party of the person who created the vacancy as at the time of the last election. We accept it. So this motion is not about the spirit of it.

I am on the record as saying that that would depend upon the time. But if you are talking about a period of a year or two then it would not be within the spirit, in my view, of the constitution to delay an appointment for that time. So this is not about that. It is not about urgency, because nothing flows from this motion at all today.

What it is about is to take a five-minute opportunity in this place to sledge Senator Colston because he deserted, in their view, the Labor Party. It is not to look at the circumstances by which he resigned from the Labor Party that might have justified that course of action. According to the Labor Party he must be punished because if he isn't adequately punished how can they maintain discipline over others? That is what this is all about.

Do not charge him, do not try him, but find him guilty and use every vehicle that this parliament presents to hound him out of office, then you feel that you can exercise sufficient discipline over the rest of the rabble that still makes up the Australian Labor Party. Madam President, there was no attempt made by Senator Faulkner to argue urgency. You did not hear for one minute an attempt to argue urgency and he has not made out his case. (Time expired)

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

—I know. Will I have an opportunity to do this later though, Madam President, if it goes ahead? I will foreshadow it.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Campbell interjecting—
Senator Faulkner interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Just a moment, Senator Kernot. Stop the clock, please. I cannot hear what Senator Kernot is saying, and I need to be able to.

—Madam President, the motion as it now stands is preoccupied with two‐party politics. My foreshadowed amendment, in my view, reflects the reality of the composition of the Senate, which is why I have asked for a recognised party represented in the Senate to be included in part (c) of the original motion. As to the matter of urgency—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You can do that, Brian. You can do that, Senator Harradine. As to the matter of urgency, Senator Faulkner has outlined the statements made by Queensland Premier Borbidge. I think that, irrespective of the party involved in this, it is the principle that is important. As the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) said yesterday in the House of Representatives, it is important that the spirit and the letter of the constitution be followed. I agree with that.

SPEECH.PARA: It was the disgraceful antics—the tricks, the taunting, the flouting of convention—by former Queensland Premier Sir Joh Bjelke‐Petersen which were the catalyst for my entering politics in Queensland. I have seen the Fitzgerald inquiry and the results which followed such a long period of National Party politics in Queensland. I have seen the constitutional amendment that was necessary as a result of those antics. I can tell you I am not about to stand by and watch a repeat of those antics in the form of the current Queensland National Party Premier. This parliament should take every opportunity, in my view, to spell out its views and to place whatever protections it possibly can against the tricks and antics of the current Queensland National Party Premier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —What this substantive resolution is about, what we are debating the urgency of at the moment, is the fact that we regard Senator Hill as a very likeable person, but we do not trust his political word on this particular matter. Firstly, the fact is that when Senator Baume was appointed to New York we in the Labor Party offered him a pair whenever he wanted to leave, but he stuck around for a few weeks. Yet it was put up in the gallery, `Oh, Senator Baume is staying here because the Labor Party hasn't offered him a pair.' The offer was made on day one, and it was extant for the whole time he was here.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, under the unfortunate circumstances of the passing of Senator John Panizza, on the very day that that occurred we offered a pair until the replacement arrives right here in this chamber. Thirdly, when Senator Bob Woods announced that he intended to resign on 1 March, we offered a pair from the very moment of his announcement to when his replacement comes back here to this chamber. This motion seeks to have that as the view of the whole Senate. The whole Senate, in fact—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order on relevance. The motion is one of urgency. Now Senator Ray is dealing precisely with it and mentioned the resolution. He said, `What this resolution is about.' I would suggest that his attention ought to be drawn to the motion, which is one of urgency, and why this is supposed to be urgent.

—On the point of order: firstly, you are allowed to develop what the motion is about to go on to prove its urgency. Secondly, Senator Harradine should know that the standing orders were specifically amended to cut down the half‐hour speeches for suspension of standing orders so that these points of order would not be continually taken merely to frustrate a senator making a contribution.
—The present debate is on the matter of urgency. I regard you as setting the scene for that, and would ask you to continue.

—Let me relate it directly back. As I have indicated, on three occasions since the coalition has come to government we have indicated in circumstances where there was a vacancy or a potential vacancy that we would offer pairs. What we are starting to wonder about in terms of Mr Borbidge's statement on the Sunday program is whether all conventions are going to be thrown out. That is why it is urgent we discuss it today.

SPEECH.PARA: This chamber operates on two bases: the first is standing orders; the second is convention and accepted practice. If it is good enough, just for opportunistic reasons, for the coalition to go down the opportunistic road and say, `Oh, hold on. We're not going to offer pairs in future when these circumstances occur,' it should be sorted out today so we all know the ground rules. We know how often the coalition break convention, break rules, in their pursuit of power. Their sense of decency simply does not exist on these issues. We know from negotiations in this chamber, when we negotiate the future of how this chamber will operate, that suddenly it disappears. In 1983, we granted pairs for a deputy president's vote. What happens 13 years later? `Oh, no. Sorry. You don't get pairs in reciprocation,' even though we had signed the sheet on the pairs situation.

Then the will of the Senate comes in. We have had this debate seven times before. When crucial coalition members miss divisions that can change the total outcome of legislation, we on this side of the chamber have always granted a re‐vote. On the one occasion that it happened on the other side, they forced us to go through 12 divisions—12 divisions that you well remember, Madam President, because it was only through your graciousness and wit that it was resolved. Twelve divisions to rectify the situation.

The urgency of this, for Senator Harradine and anyone else, is that we want to know what the ground rules are in future. We want to know whether, if we play by the rules and we play by convention, it is going to be reciprocated, or whether we are going to have a new standard in politics in this country where we are the bunnies playing by the rules and where, at the first opportunity that the coalition have, they will rip us up; they will not obey those conventions. It is urgent that we settle this now so that future relationships in this chamber can be established on a basis of commonsense and decency. This has become urgent now because we have seen from the Sunday interview with Mr Borbidge that he has no conception, no conception at all, of the conventions and political principle. I think one journalist put it very aptly: either Mr Borbidge is very stupid or he is getting very poor advice to say what he said last weekend.

One other point I want to make is in response to Senator Hill. He says that we are persecuting a senator. The fact is, if it is a matter of principle, there is nothing wrong with a senator resigning from a political party in this place. The crime is staying here. If you are principled and if you do believe for some reason you no longer share the philosophy and views of your party, you put a letter in to you, Madam President. You resign from this chamber and you go. You do not stay here for grubby venal reasons. You do not sell your services to the other side. That is a tradition of the Labor Party and anyone who rats on the Labor Party will get exactly what this quisling Quasimodo from Queensland got.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Ray's display there really shows to all honourable senators and to all listening to this debate what is driving Senator Ray and what is driving the Australian Labor Party. I seek not even to make comment, because I hope that the people of Australia—
—You talk about Noel Crichton-Browne. Tell us about Colston.

—We will talk about Noel Crichton-Browne as well, Senator Ray. As you know, Madam President, Crichton-Browne's name should be raised in this debate because it demonstrates how these people opposite speak with forked tongues when it comes to talking about standing by convention.
—On a point of order, Madam President. Interjections are disorderly. We at least had the grace to listen to Senator Ray. They ought to listen to Senator Campbell in the same spirit.
—It is a short debate and I think people should listen to what people have to say before they make up their mind how they vote.

—They do not want to listen to what I say because they will not like what they are going to hear. Senator Ray talks about the standing orders and how this place needs to run on a couple of planks: one is the standing orders and the second is convention and accepted practice.

SPEECH.PARA: Labor, through their leader in this place, Senator Faulkner, and their shadow leader, Senator Ray, would have us believe that Labor are the only people in this place who stand by those conventions. All of the people who listen to the Senate know that this Leader of the Opposition chooses to abide by those conventions when it suits him or when it suits his political purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the evidence?
—The evidence is in the Hansard day by day. Senator Faulkner, as you know—
—Very, very yellow bellied.
—Senator Faulkner, withdraw those remarks please.
—If I said anything unparliamentary, I withdraw it.

—Madam President, as you know better than most, Senator Faulkner chooses to abide by your rulings and chooses to abide by the conventions of the Senate only when it suits him. He chooses to draw your attention to those conventions and to the standing orders when it suits him. He decides to ignore those standing orders and those conventions, as does Senator Robert Ray, when it suits him. When it suits their political case to say, `We are the upholders of the conventions of the Senate,' that is when Senator Ray upholds them.

SPEECH.PARA: Talking about conventions of the Senate, I turn to our friends on the coalition opposition benches under Senator Kernot and move to the urgency of this motion. If Senator Kernot or any of the people opposite thought it was an urgent matter to come to a vote today, they would have allowed this matter to have gone formal.

Senator Kernot can do what she wants, but what most people do when they pull up the Notice Paper and see a motion they do not quite agree with—and I suggest Senator Kernot did this to Senator Faulkner at some time in the last 24 hours; Senator Kernot can seek leave to deny what I say is true if it is not true—is say, `I suggest that, if you put in these new words, we would support that motion.' Senator Faulkner can deny that that took place. It might have taken place through officers.

After the second or third question during question time, Senator Faulkner strolled down to Senator Kernot, pulled out the Notice Paper—I suggest this happened; you tell me if I am wrong—and said, `What I propose is: the coalition will probably oppose this, so let us make sure we have a debate. You oppose formality.'

BREAK.PARA: With the connivance of the fourth faction of the Labor Party, with the connivance of the coalition in opposition, the Australian Democrats, Senator Faulkner ensured that this matter was not dealt with as a matter of urgency. By using a connivance that was devised, I thought fairly effectively, by Senator Brown and Senator Margetts to make sure that they could have a debate on issues, they ensured that this matter could not be dealt with urgently. By their very deeds, by their throwing out of convention and by their abuse of the standing orders here this afternoon, they have ensured that this matter cannot be dealt with urgently.

I say to Senator Ray, to Senator Faulkner and to the leader of the Democrat faction of the coalition in opposition: do not go around saying that you stand by conventions. Do not quote my old friend Noel Crichton-Browne's name back to me, when you were the people who stopped Noel Crichton-Browne becoming Deputy President because you chucked out convention in 1993. Do not quote convention. Do not quote principles. Do not quote the rules, because the first rule you have thrown out by even proposing this motion is a very important rule in Australia—the presumption of innocence.

Do not tell us about principle, because Senator Ray, Senator Faulkner and most of that disgraceful mob on the other side treat conventions as important when it suits their cause. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the urgency of the motion moved by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner). Because of the debate we have had here today, it is quite clear to me that this is an urgent issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Since I became whip, there have been a number of resignations, and, unfortunately, one death of a senator. As Senator Ray has quite clearly outlined, on each of those occasions as Labor whip, I have said immediately to the government whip, `We will of course pair that senator for all votes from now on.' When Senator Baume decided to retire there was a great deal of interest in the press as to whether or not he would be paired. I rang John Panizza and assured him that Baume would be paired—and, when we returned to parliament, he was.

But the reason for then Senator Baume not going quickly—and he was very keen to get to America—was that the Liberal Party were about to rat on a convention when it came to the election of the Deputy President. At that time they tried to ensure that the two Labor members—one of whom was in a sick bed in Adelaide—whom they had paired in a letter on that day would not be allowed to vote. The Liberal Party said, `Despite the letter we wrote to you concerning the pairs for today, when it comes to the vote for Deputy President, when it comes to us voting for Mal Colston and fulfilling our part of the deal, you cannot have a pair.'

I am very suspicious of their principles on these issues because, when it came to the crunch, when their self‐interest was at stake, they tried to rat. Only after a very embarrassing debate did Senator Hill finally agree to the pairing arrangements being honoured for that vote. That was my first experience.

My second experience was on the death of John Panizza, a man for whom I had a great deal of respect. He, as soon as he had died, was paired by the opposition. That pair arrangement has remained in existence, while the WA Liberal Party fights out its factional fights over his replacement. Until he is replaced, he will continue to be paired. In fact, he has been paired as an additional number over the five normal pairs granted because obviously the circumstances under which he departed were way beyond the Liberal Party's control. So we have again offered a pair.

Thirdly, we come to Senator Woods. He announced his resignation. We immediately made it clear in this chamber and privately that he would be paired—and that has been the case. In fact, he has hardly been here since the announcement of that decision. But today in the Financial Review—and this is one of the reasons for this motion being urgent—it has been reported that Senator Woods feels he cannot resign because he is not sure about the pairing arrangements.

Pass this motion and Senator Woods can go. You can be rid of him as you want to be. He claims he cannot retire because he is not sure that pairing arrangements, as proposed by Senator Faulkner in this motion, will be honoured. Vote for this motion, and he can go. This is your chance. Let Bob Woods go. Vote for this motion, and he can go.

BREAK.PARA: This bill introduces an historic innovation to public administration in Australia with the establishment of the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency, which was announced as part of the 1996 budget.

The establishment of the Agency will be a major change in service delivery arrangements for the Commonwealth. Although it will initially encompass the full suite of income security payments and services currently provided by the Department of Social Security, together with a number of employment and child care services, it will have the potential to add to these over time. It will provide an administrative framework for integrating access to Commonwealth services by consolidating services so that, where possible, people can get the help they need in one place.

The government's objectives in creating the Agency are to provide a much better standard of service delivery to the community and to individuals; and to increase service delivery efficiency and effectiveness. The government wishes to shift the focus and direction of customer service from the mechanics of transaction and process to one which is centred on individuals and their needs. The scope of the Agency's activities will cover services to the retired, families, the unemployed, carers and widows, the short term incapacitated and people with disabilities. It will be the public presence for some of the most sensitive social responsibilities of government.

It makes sense to consolidate services so that, where possible, people can access them in one place. For example, unemployed people will only have to go to one Agency office to seek income support rather than having to go to both DSS and CES offices respectively as at present. In this way the Agency will be a significant step to reducing the complexity of government for individuals and the community. The Agency will deliver services for a number of portfolios and integrate these into a common point of customer contact. The clear principle underlying the concept of the Agency is the government's commitment to put the needs of people for high quality service delivery above the boundaries of Commonwealth departments and agencies.

The Agency will be an organisation focused on, and specialising in, customer service. It will do this by simplifying and streamlining service delivery through an integrated and national network of offices. It will have a Charter, including a guarantee to customers of certain standards of service. The current DSS network of regional offices, together with its Teleservice Centres, Family Service Centres and Retirement Service Centres, will go to the Agency and form the core of its service outlets. It will also take on some offices that are now part of the CES network along with the Student Assistance Centres. The Agency will also provide a means for integrating the existing services for some groups needing specialist assistance and continue to recognise that the arrangements for these groups of clients require sensitive and careful consideration.

The Agency will be located in the Social Security portfolio, given that the largest component of its activities will be the administration of entitlements under Social Security legislation. In designing the framework for the Agency, the government has taken into account the need for ministerial involvement to ensure accountability; sufficient flexibility to allow greater capacity for innovation and improved customer service; and the need to ensure a strong partnership between policy and process design and service delivery.

The Agency is a core part of government operations. All the mainstream legislation for the operation of Commonwealth departments and agencies will apply to this Agency. It will be subject to the Audit Act, Finance Regulations and Finance Directions. This reflects the fact that the Agency will not be a separate entity from the Commonwealth. The government considers that these scrutiny and accountability arrangements are central to the management structures for the Agency given that it will be responsible for the day to day administration of large sums of public monies.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

These amendments have the effect of indexing the maximum income a person can earn and still receive the incentives by reference to increases in average weekly earnings. BREAK.PARA: Without indexation, the real level of wages allowed while a person can still receive the incentives is lowered.
