SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can advise that the government is opposed to the amendments moved by Senator Neal. For a start, the government in its forward estimates did not take into account any indexation. But there are other reasons for the government's opposition, and I thank Senator Neal for giving the government notice of these amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite simply, the government has already made provision in the bill for the minister to determine by a disallowable instrument in writing the threshold amount for incentives. That is provided for in paragraph 1 of clause 5‐3 on page 17 of the bill. There will therefore be scope for the incentive to be reviewed by the minister from time to time to ensure that the incentives match the operating environment of the day.

Automatic indexation of incentives perhaps sends the opposite signal to people. It would ensure that thresholds would invariably move every year through the linkage to average weekly earnings. Superficially, it may look consumer friendly but it can also be a signal to funds that we expect, as a matter of course, that there would be upward movements in their premiums. There are other aspects to the government's opposition to this, but they are basically the main points that I would put forward at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the parliamentary secretary is not prepared to accept the amendment—and, as you say, there is provision by regulation to increase the threshold level—will you give an undertaking on behalf of the government that, in fact, the government will maintain the real value of this threshold so that there is not reduction in the real income level?

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —While the parliamentary secretary is seeking some advice, I wish to indicate that the Democrats are of the view that, wherever possible, as a matter of fairness, we should move to index and, in this particular case, I wonder whether the government really can rely on the excuse that they have not budgeted for this. I understand it is normal practice; it is done in many other areas. I call on the minister to think again. Surely he does not really believe that health insurance funds are not going to raise their premiums?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Neal has a very good case. I think the government should look at this. It is all very well to say that these matters will be attended to by a regulation which is a disallowable instrument but, of course, the power of the parliament in respect of disallowable instruments is not the same as it is when these matters are being considered by the parliament during the committee stage of the bill. As I hear the parliamentary secretary, the government is not radically opposed to the principle behind Senator Neal's proposed amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Under those circumstances, I would have thought that it would be better to have the amendments to the legislation than to leave the matter to the vagaries of regulations and also to the vagaries of what might occur if those regulations are disallowed. You would then go back into negotiations and you might end up with something worse than you had before you disallowed them.

BREAK.PARA: It also surprises me that the government has not budgeted for such a measure. It does that all the time. One difficulty that I foresee, of course, is what happens if the basis upon which the adjustment is made drops—but that probably would not make much difference at all. I think the principle that Senator Neal has espoused is a good one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the various points put by Senator Neal, Senator Lees and Senator Harradine, the government is opposed to these amendments. There was no indexation in the family tax incentives, so this is quite consistent with the government's approach to this and other areas. We see these incentives as part of the wider comprehensive assistance to families which the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) promised the Australian people last March when we went to the polls.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that the minister's power of periodic determination, as already provided for in the legislation, will be exercised with reference to the incentives alignment with the family tax initiative. In relation to Senator Harradine's comment, the disallowance procedure in the Senate does, of course, place scrutiny on the minister's behaviour and it does have that aspect of transparency—it does have the parliamentary content in it which allows the opposition and Independents to play some part in it. We would say that that provides sufficient flexibility.

As for the forward estimates, we went to the people of Australia last March and we put the incentives to them. The platform was much as I said was the case with the family tax incentives, and indexation did not form part of that. So the government looked ahead with the mandate that it had and planned its path accordingly, without taking on board indexation, because that was not part of our policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I fear that there may be some misunderstanding on the part of the parliamentary secretary about the impact of our amendment. What the indexation is aimed at is not the actual amount of the incentive, but the income level at which the incentive cuts in. As such, it would not really be affected by some assumption that the cost of private health insurance might go up. What I am talking about and what this amendment is aimed at is not the amount of the incentive but at what level of real income the incentive cuts in. Maybe you could redirect your response to that area.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —Any indexation will allow for a change in the environment in the course of the year and could well allow for extra payments to be made; and that, of course, does not come within the forecast when we are dealing with specified thresholds as we have here. What you are advocating is a situation which involves indexation, which is very different from what the government is proposing here. That, in itself, will have a variation in the forward estimates. As I have said, in the bill before you, there is the ability for the minister to review the situation on an annual basis. It is really like comparing apples with pears—indexation as opposed to a fixed threshold. One is a moveable feast; the other is not.

—Am I correct in understanding your argument that this Senate should not amend the legislation because then it would require the government to amend its forward estimates? Is that the sole argument in opposition?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is not. I indicated that there were other aspects to the government's opposition. I pointed them out. Of course, there is this mechanism for review by the minister. As well as that there was the prospect of the fact that upward movements in the premiums would be expected as a matter of course. It is not often in these situations that the premiums would come down. Looking at history one can safely say that there would be an expectation that premiums would go up on an indexed basis. That is another aspect of it.

SPEECH.PARA: The other part about it is that what the opposition would have us do is complicated to administer, creates greater uncertainty for families and income tax payers and undermines the climate of stability which we are trying to create for private health funds, their customers and the wider private health sector. Quite frankly, this is an attempt under the guise of concern for consumers to undermine public confidence in these incentives to private health insurance. These are other aspects to the government's opposition. The fact is that we are providing some certainty in the threshold. Indexation does not provide the same certainty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I hate to labour this point but I still feel that the parliamentary secretary seems to have missed the point. The proposition contained in the amendment is that the level of income a person must have to receive this incentive should be maintained, not that there should be a variation in the amount of the incentive. I can well understand the parliamentary secretary's proposition if what we are proposing was indexation of the actual amount of the incentive. If you assume that the amount of money that was being paid to the recipient went up each year, from that you could draw an assumption that there is a presumption that premiums of private health insurance were also going to be going up.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that on that question I am not completely convinced in any case because I think experience does tell us that private health insurance has been going up quite markedly for some period of time. What I put to you is that there is no connection whatsoever between the level of income that a person is allowed to have and still receive the incentive and some presumption about the increasing cost of private health insurance.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Neal, are you saying that under your amendments which involve index ation there is no prospect of a change in eligibility of any health consumer and that what you are saying is that your indexation provides a situation which is unchanging during the course of a financial year? Surely you are going to have some change if you index this threshold. Where do you say that your situation remains unchanged and provides the same stability as the government's proposal?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not say that the situation is unchanged all together or there would be no point in the amendment. What I am saying is that our amendment does not have the effect of changing the amount that is actually paid to an eligible recipient. All it does is ensure that the level of income which defines the recipient remains the same in real terms. Let me give a rough example. Say the level was $100 and over time because of the effects of inflation that person's income went up to $110. Because the threshold was $100 they would no longer be eligible, though in real terms their income was still equivalent to the value of $100 as it is at the present time.

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of time on your proposal would mean that a person who was originally eligible for the incentive would no longer be eligible even though in real terms their income remains the same. Therefore, over time, the way your proposal is, a smaller and smaller group of people would become eligible for the incentive. I do not believe that is what your intention is. If I misunderstand and it is your intention, maybe you could advise the Senate and I would not persist with this argument.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only say that the government agrees to disagree on this point in that a sufficient mechanism is provided for in the bill for the minister's discretion to be exercised on an annual basis in relation to the threshold. The government believes that that is an appropriate course to follow.

—Might I therefore receive a response to my question some time back now as to whether you are prepared to give an undertaking that the government will increase the level of threshold over time with variation in average weekly earnings?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can say that the government will look at this each year in the budgetary context.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me that what the good parliamentary secretary opposite has said, completely unsmilingly—he should be provoked to smile, and I would have thought this was one of those things that might have had Senator Harradine on his feet—that each year in the budget context the government should be given carte blanche to raise or lower the threshold is a very bold proposal indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: People need to understand exactly what it is that the government is claiming. There is to be no adjustment to make sure that people who are eligible this year remain eligible next year. There is none of that. There is no security or assurance for people.

The points that Senator Neal has just raised are very important. What happens if a family that is eligible this year is rendered ineligible next year? What kind of assurance can you give people that the government will not arbitrarily say, `The threshold that is $70,000 this year is going to be $50,000 next year,' when you see that the savings are not very much or that the people are still fleeing from private health insurance? I think the parliament and the people deserve better than that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —The taxation rates are not indexed. They stand there as a specified graduated level at which people are taxed. These are not changed during the year. What we are proposing is that there be a specified threshold which everyone knows. There is no misleading of people at all. It provides them with a clear direction.

BREAK.PARA: At the end of the year during the budgetary process, the minister can then reassess the social and economic environment and can accordingly amend the threshold if appropriate. I think that is an appropriate course to deal with this issue. It is consistent with our family tax incentives, where we have imposed specific thresholds with no indexation. I say to Senator Crowley that no-one would be led astray by what the government is proposing. It is clear. It is in black and white. It is simple. In fact, it is the simplicity of this proposal that makes it appealing.

TALK.START.PARA: —That may well be the case, but I am still not clear on what the intention of the government is. Is it the intention of the government that over time the threshold income level in real terms will reduce and fewer people will become eligible? Or is the intention of the government to vary the level of the income threshold over time and ensure that the real level of income remains the same and that the same number of people will continue to be eligible? Regardless of the methodology, whether through legislation or regulation, what is the intention of the government in putting forward this legislation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government's intention is to allow as many people as possible to be eligible, but that is dictated by the constraints of the day and the social and economic environment that I mentioned earlier. One does not know exactly what will happen from one year to the other.

SPEECH.PARA: As the opposition would well know from its days in government, the government has said that it wants these incentives to be available to as many Australians as possible. The government cannot say at this stage what the position will be next year, but it can say to the people of Australia, `There is a specific threshold. That is how we are operating.' SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

—In March 1996 the number of people with private health insurance was 33.9 per cent and it is now 33.2 per cent. This participation rate has been declining over the years. TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —We would expect that this would bottom out within 12 months of the introduction of these incentives. If that was a figure of 33 per cent, that would be reasonable. I think the situation here is that you firstly have to stem the flow of the exodus of people from private health insurance. You stem the flow and then you build on that once it has bottomed out. I think you have alluded to that in your comments.

SPEECH.PARA: You noted that the rate of decline per quarter had halved during the last year. The reduction in the decline in private health insurance is due to the fact that the government has made its position very clear. People realise that these incentives are going to come into play, and that has already stemmed the flow of people who are leaving private health funding.

The government first has to stem this flow, which even Bob Carr, the Premier of New South Wales, said placed great pressure on the public hospitals in that state. It has been acknowledged by many people from your side of politics that the decline of private health insurance is of no value to the state of health in this country. The government's first objective is to stem that flow. If it bottomed out at 33 per cent, that would be a reasonable figure.

TALK.START.PARA: —I assume that since you say `bottoming out', you expect it will then grow thereafter. What is the objective of the government in terms of the rate of growth? How much do you expect participation will grow by? How long will it take before the ultimate objective of peak participation as a result of this legislation is reached?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us get to the state of bottoming out first before we predict at what rate it will grow. A lot depends on the economic conditions of the time. I believe that the government's first step in this priority is to stem the flow, as I have said, restabilise the situation and then plot the course of an upward path of participation in private health. At this stage we are still too far away from that growth to make any predictions of any value. The priority of this government is to stem the flow in the first instance.

—I certainly understand very clearly that the first priority of this government is to stem the flow but, as I understand it, the minister said that he anticipated participation would grow by two per cent. Is it intended that that will be the final level; that is, 35 per cent, two per cent up from 33 per cent? Is it anticipated that that will be the only growth as a result of this legislation, or will growth continue? If it does continue, what level will it reach before it stops, as a result of this legislation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only say to Senator Neal that that was not an absolute prediction by the minister. That is not something which is absolute. It is very hard to predict how an industry such as this will progress in the future, after having the rate of participation stabilised. There can be no absolute prediction on this at this point in time. It is, frankly, asking, `How long is a piece of string?' I repeat my prior point to you that the government's first priority is to stem the flow, to have a stabilisation in the rate of private health insurance participation, and then take it from there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —If I have what the parliamentary secretary is saying correct, you are saying that you will be happy with a bottoming out and that, therefore, we are spending $1.7 billion on people who are already in private health insurance. So we are putting $1.7 billion into people who are already in private health insurance.

SPEECH.PARA: I note what you say about putting pressure on the public system with people dropping out. Obviously we are, but surely a better way to relieve pressure on the public system is to put $1.7 billion into the public system. Then I think we could predict what the outcome would be. The outcome would be a considerable improvement in the public health system and in the health of Australians. So here we have $1.7 billion going into the private system, and you say, `Well, we can't really predict what is going to happen.' I suggest we could predict what would happen if we put $1.7 billion into public hospital and community health services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lees, I would suggest to you that that would only provide a bandaid solution in a very short-term situation. In fact, the money that is being spent is designed to keep people in private health and also to attract people back to private health insurance. We are facing, as Senator Neal mentioned, a continuing loss of people from private health insurance. So you have to give them the incentive to stay there. You also have to show those people who are have left it and those other people who have hitherto not been members of it that there is some benefit in joining up. That is where the attraction of these incentives lies.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not just wasting money on people who are already members of private health insurance. It is keeping them there. That is what we have to do: stop them from leaving in the first instance. Then we have to bring back those people who left. We have then got to bring in people who previously have not been members.

BREAK.PARA: If we spend $1.7 billion on health across Australia, it will be noticed for only a moment and then it will be gone. This is laying the foundation for a greater participation in private health insurance. I think all of us in this chamber today acknowledge the fact that it is this exodus from private health insurance that is causing problems in our public health system.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have any intention to stifle debate, and I will call Senator Lees in a moment, but I would remind the committee that the question before the chair is that Senator Neal's requests for amendments be agreed to. We may be straying into debate on the next amendment before us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can't let this go. I realise that time is short in this chamber and we need to move on, and I probably will visit this matter again when I get to my amendments. But can I suggest, Minister, that the reason many people are leaving private health insurance is that it is a bad deal. It does not make sense.

SPEECH.PARA: Not only do premiums continue to rise—you have no ability to cap that; you have no ability to contain costs in the private system—but people also face so many additional costs. That is why, when privately insured people end up in the public hospital system in emergencies, they do not disclose that they are privately insured. They know quite frequently if they go as a private patient into the public system they will get additional bills from their anaesthetist, their surgeon, et cetera.

If you really are keen about people looking after themselves, then why do we have before us again in this package of legislation the move to restrict people's ability, if they spend on themselves—that is, insured or uninsured—to actually claim some rebate on that? We are going to be looking—I think it is in the taxation bill as part of this package, the measure we have already rejected in this chamber—at a very popular measure only with the health insurance companies because they want further pressure on people to go back to their bad deals.

BREAK.PARA: We have a measure here that is moving in exactly the opposite direction to what you are standing up here and saying: that it is so important to take pressure off the public system. If your government were consistent, that particular measure would not be in here.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation with premiums is that if you attract more people to participate in a scheme such as this, it will in turn contribute to keeping premiums down. If you get more healthy people involved in private health insurance who never have to claim—that is, after all, where the insurance funds are able to keep their premiums down; it just makes sense with the more people you have participating—there is a greater chance of keeping those premiums down, especially with the attraction of younger people, who will not be claiming as much as older people. That in itself will keep the premiums down. I think that is something which is self-fulfilling and that is the attraction of private health insurance, where it is widely participated in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —I actually wanted to ask you a slightly different question. I suppose it is called `Yours is not a bad statement of an article of faith.' There is absolutely no evidence to support what you are saying—that people who are not currently insured will actually go looking for $800 or thereabouts so as to get a benefit of $125 if they are single people. That is a huge amount of money, and why would you want to spend that? Why, when the only thing you get if you are privately insured is a bill? You might actually get a doctor of choice and you might get into a hospital bed faster, but for a lot of people, particularly if you are healthy, why would you want to do that?

SPEECH.PARA: The interesting thing is this. Senator Lees has spelt it out. There seems to be, across the chamber, almost a polarising of views here, where neither side can hear or be persuaded by the other's argument. Senator Lees has spelt it out very carefully: private health insurance is a very bad deal for people. With $125 at this stage to reduce an ever increasing premium, which has already written off the incentives, why would people do it, particularly if their best guess is that they do not want to use it?

Secondly, I do want to ask you to address again the other point that Senator Lees made: why would you also have the inconsistency of an incentive in one hand and a tax benefit lost out of the other hand? It is just very contradictory. Can you please explain?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crowley, when people insure their motor vehicles, they do not set out to have accidents. In fact, when you insure your household contents, you do not set out for your house to burn to the ground, or to have those contents stolen.
—Some do.

—I hear Senator Evans saying, `Some do.' In very rare cases, Senator Evans, and they are normally prosecuted. People do take out private health insurance, because you never know what is around the corner. If you are young and healthy, you do want the choice of your own doctor and you do want to be able to get to a hospital bed faster.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a lot of people who could have an injury of some sort but who are otherwise quite healthy. They would embark on private health insurance for obvious reasons—because of those benefits you yourself alluded to: choice of doctor, choice of hospital and the availability of a bed. I can tell you that I had that situation quite recently, for a very minor matter, and that was a great facility afforded to me because of private health insurance. I did not expect to have that, but I was glad to have the insurance there when it was needed.

That is the benefit of having insurance and that is when you say to people, `Look, there is this incentive for you to insure.' Everyone looks to the future and what might happen. You do it with your motor car, you do it with your house and you should do it with yourself.

BREAK.PARA: Your other point was in relation to providing incentives and—what was it—tax? You were referring to the surcharge; is that right?

TALK.START.PARA: —The 20c in the dollar if you spend more than $1,000. Has it gone up to $1,500?
—Is that not tax legislation?
—It is; it is part of this package.
—It is part of the package.

—Could I just clarify what I think Senator Crowley is asking; that is, why is it 20c in the dollar when, previously, it was always 30c in the dollar? Secondly, why have you upped the amount from $1,000 to $1,500? Surely to goodness that is not giving any real incentive to join health funds?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we are on another bill. I realise that we have strayed, but perhaps I can say this for the parliamentary secretary's benefit. You just gave an example of where someone may choose, as you chose, to use a private hospital. Why is this government trying to push us all through the private health insurance funds? Why can't we choose, as more and more Australians are doing, to put the $700, $800, $1,300 or $1,400—depending on how much you are paying for your private health insurance—into a bank and let it sit there. Then, if you should need a private hospital bed or a private doctor, you will have some money that you can spend of your own? In other words, you are self-insuring. People who are self-insuring, I believe, should not be penalised.

SPEECH.PARA: Why can't people who are choosing to use the private system—funding themselves in the private system, not relying on health insurance but saying, `Okay, I have to have this operation. I won't go into the public system and put pressure on a bed. I will choose the private option'—pay for themselves? There was a system where, after you had spent $1,000 in a year, you got 20c in the dollar back. Your government is trying to put that up to $1,500 a year. That means that you are actually looking at a disincentive for people opting out of the public system and going private.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the parliamentary secretary, I would appeal to the committee to remember that the question before the chair is that Senator Neal's request for amendments be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —Because I did not get in here at the beginning of this committee debate, may I get some clarification? I particularly asked a question about the Private Health Insurance Incentives Bill. Am I able to ask that now or do we wait until these amendments are dealt with?
—Now would be a good place to ask it.
—I refer to clause 3‐3. I think I gave an indication of this question during my speech in the second reading debate. Clause 3‐3 (2), `Income test—policies covering only one person', states:

SPEECH.PARA: This subclause provides that the persons whose taxable incomes are to be taken into account when determining eligibility for the scheme in respect of a policy covering one person are:

(b) if the person covered under the policy is a dependent child, the incomes of each parent who is paying premiums for the policy or arranging for a third party to pay premiums for the policy and of any partner of each such parent.

In the case of a marriage breakdown when two separated parents may each contribute to private health insurance for a child, the way I read this is that it could be that each partner of those separated parents now newly married could also have their income assessed. I do not believe that is the intention of this clause, but I would like to have an assurance that that is not a possible interpretation and that therefore there may not be the need for an amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will take a husband and wife situation. When there is a breakdown of the marriage and separation occurs, and the husband is paying the premium and the wife has care and control of the child, then the mother will be income tested, despite the fact that the husband is paying the premium. In that case, if the wife enters into a new relationship, then I understand that the new partner is tested.

SPEECH.PARA: I will make that clear because there are a number of permutations on this. The husband who is paying the premium for the child and the wife for the private health insurance is income tested. But when the wife enters into a relationship with a third party, shall we say, that third party is income tested. I think that is how it works. I will just check that again with the department. That is on the basis of the wife being covered in the policy. I think I might have said that earlier. But, if that was not clear, I reiterate that it covers a situation where the wife is covered in the policy as well as the child.

When a husband and wife separate and the wife has the child and only the child is covered, then the husband is income tested. That is regardless of whether the wife enters into another relationship, as long as the husband continues to pay the premium. So, if only the child is covered—this is different from the last situation I gave you, where the wife is covered as well—and the husband is paying, then if the wife enters into a new relationship that third party is not assessed; the income testing still attaches to the husband who is paying the premium. When a husband and wife split and they are sharing equally in payments, then it would appear that you income test both of them. I do not know whether that assists you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not quite. I am very pleased that I did ask this question, because what was vaguely confusing is now splendidly confusing. Families around Australia who might be interested in this incentive would be assisted if you could produce a bit of paper, certainly for me, that spells out all those variations. If the father is paying a premium that covers the mother and the child, even though the marriage has broken down and they are not together, then the mother's income would be taken into account, as would be the income of her new partner if she partnered?
—Yes.
—That should be very interesting. I presume that, if the father has now re‐partnered, his partner's income will be taken into account?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —It may assist you if I get a schedule from the department to cover these permutations. I will undertake to have that available during the committee stage, and please feel free to get back to us on it. But I think it would save time if we got you a schedule of this which would make it abundantly clear.

—I thank you for that. That would perhaps allow us to see whether or not, in relation to these words that gave me concerns—and from what you are telling me my concerns are right—at least one new partner, if not both, of a divorced couple could well have their income assessed in terms of eligibility for incentive, for example, for a child. Could we have as many variations as you can think of on this? If you want to give me more than I ask for, that is fine. I was particularly looking at, in terms of who is eligible for incentive and depending on who is paying for it, how many people's incomes could be involved in being assessed as eligible—that is, how far out partners of split couples get their income into this assessment. It would certainly help me very much if you could provide that.
—Yes, we'll do that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —When I last asked a question, I think I asked what the objectives of the government were in terms of the level of participation in private health insurance. On that occasion, the response of the parliamentary secretary was that the government could not predict what would happen. I am not interested so much in a direct prediction about what may occur; I am interested in being advised what the objectives of this government are. It is my view that, when taking any course of action, it is important for two reasons to know what your objectives are: first, to see if you are really achieving your objectives and, secondly, to develop some performance indicators so that, as time passes, you can see whether your course of action was effective.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that the government is only half‐confident in saying that the participation rate will drop to or bottom out at 33 per cent. If you do a few sums, the participation rate at the moment is dropping 0.25 per cent each quarter, which is exactly one per cent each year. The Productivity Commission tells us that a one per cent drop costs the government, in health terms, $300,000. If you compare that amount with the $600,000 per annum that this incentive will cost this government, to me it does not add up—you save $300,000 by paying $600,000.

It would seem to me that the government must have in mind some objective as to increasing participation to make it worth while. I do not want a prediction from the parliamentary secretary about what the participation rate should reach; I want to know what the government's objective is, in introducing this legislation, as to the increase in participation rates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short term there may be a dip. I am saying that it will not necessarily stop at 33 per cent and go no further. It could go below the 33 per cent mark, then come up and stabilise at that point and grow from there. What we are about, essentially, is achieving stability. The primary object is to achieve stability and then build on that stability.

SPEECH.PARA: As was said during the second reading debate, this is not the total answer. It is only the first step in a strategic response to the current problem we face in the health sector. In the very short term you may well have a dip below that bottom line, but you will come back up to the bottom line and steady on it. The government can plot a course from there which will see a growth.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the parliamentary secretary is saying that it may well drop below that 33 per cent, how far does the government anticipate it may drop below that point? I am still not clear: does the government have as an objective increasing participation above that 33 per cent or does it expect it will only be maintained at that level and go no higher?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —There was something of a momentum established under the last government for a period of 13 years. Stopping that is somewhat like trying to stop a train, which is rather difficult. This downward trend does have a degree of momentum about it. As I have said, what the government has to achieve in the first instance is the restraint of that to achieve stability, and then the government can build on that. We cannot deal in semantics. All I can say to you is that our priorities are to stem the exodus of people from participation in private health insurance, to stabilise the situation and then build on that—in fact, much as you would do with anyone in a life‐threatening situation or someone who is injured: you stabilise them first, then you treat them and bring about a recovery. That is a very good analogy for this situation.
—What is the government's objective as to the ultimate rate of participation in private health insurance?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have said previously, as many people as can participate. We want to make these incentives available to as many people as possible. The more who can participate in private health insurance, the better. It will ease the burden on public health.

—Are you saying that this government has expended the sum of $600 million each year without really having any figure in mind about what the participation rate will end up being and how much money will be saved? I am not asking you for a prediction; I am asking you what the object of the government is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —The point was raised earlier about spending $1.7 billion in place of this. You have to look at the contribution that private health insurance participation makes—some $4 billion—which was mentioned in the second reading speech. It would be irresponsible of this government not to embark upon this strategy. The problem we face, Senator Neal, is that the situation is going nowhere fast. As I have said, we have to take it one step at a time. This is not the total answer. It is the first step in a strategic response to a problem which we inherited from the former government.

SPEECH.PARA: You might say, `You always say that,' but the fact is we have been in government one year. We are bringing in a reform which we told the people of Australia that we would bring in. This is a first step to a recovery in the health sector of this nation. That is the sum total of it. We are not providing a panacea overnight; we are providing a first step in a process of recovery. We cannot predict absolutely what the position will be in two, three or four years time. What we can say is that this will achieve a stabilisation of the situation in the first instance, thereby building a basis for recovery.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —If it is the case that the desirable object of the government is to retain as many as possible in the private health schemes and to encourage people to privately insure for their own health cover, then why is the government not recognising that there are thousands of people with non-registered fund insurance? Why are they ineligible for this incentive?

SPEECH.PARA: I give you an example. I know of a family with four children in this position. They are paying $148 a month or thereabouts and they pay the first $500 or $250. They will not be eligible for the incentive.

BREAK.PARA: I think the government should take that on board to see if they are genuinely—I acknowledge they are genuine—seeking to do something to ensure that people are responsible for their own private health insurance cover. Here is an example where clearly the legislation before us is militating against that objective.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government's position is that it only recognises the community rated funds. You are talking of a non-registered fund, is that correct?
—That's correct.

—In that situation, it is not the policy of the government to afford the same recognition to those funds. They do not make the contribution that the community rated funds do. I mentioned earlier the contribution of the private health sector to the overall health sector in a cost sense.

SPEECH.PARA: So, while the non-registered funds do not make that contribution, it really is, with respect, comparing chalk with cheese. You could well ask that family why they belong to that fund and not to one which is recognised by the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the government believe that lifetime community rating is in keeping with the coalition's promise in relation to retaining community rating?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —We do believe it is in accordance with our election promise. We believe that lifetime community rating breeds stability. It is as simple as that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —Why will the government not release the Productivity Commission's final report, which was finalised last Friday? The government has available a copy. In response to a question I asked without notice, the minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services in this place said that the report would be made public when the government gave its response.

SPEECH.PARA: I have the Department of Health and Family Services's response to that report. It is rather interesting trying to work out the recommendations from the health department's response. Why will the government not release the report when obviously it is going to have a major bearing on the whole private health insurance issue and in particular on this package of legislation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the response Senator Neal is referring to was a response to a draft report. Perhaps Senator Neal could clarify that.
—I haven't got the document with me, but it actually says `report'; it does not say `draft report'.

—That is not the final report, I am told; that is the draft report. That is obviously available to you, so you have had some knowledge of it. Therefore, I fail to see where you find yourself prejudiced by it not being released.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is rather a preposterous proposition to say that, if we can see the shadow, it is as good as having the real thing. I really think the whole debate would be assisted by having that report available. I find it really quite strange that it has not been released.

SPEECH.PARA: The only conclusion I or any reasonable person in the community might draw is that the contents of that report are not very supportive of this package of legislation. I would like the parliamentary secretary to advise the Senate whether there are any recommendations or discussions contained in the report which may affect this legislation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am in no position to advise you of that, but the government's situation in this is no different to that of the previous govern ment's. On a number of occasions reports were made to the government during the course of legislative process, and the legislative process was not halted because of that. This situation is no different to prior situations in which the previous government found itself. When the report is made public, no doubt that will be debated in this very chamber. It will be for the opposition then to take what course of action it sees fit, and the government.

—I am not asking that the legislative process be halted. I am merely suggesting that, in the interests of good government and properly assessing all the facts before making a decision, the Senate would be greatly assisted by provision of that report. I would like to be advised by the government of what good public policy basis they have for not releasing it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only say that it is not being released at this point in time and it will be released when it is appropriate to do so. That will be decided by the minister.
—I mentioned in my comments a 15‐page document that would be used to assess income. Is this the appropriate place to ask about that?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I suppose we can talk about the form now. If Senator Crowley wants to see a copy of the draft, I have one here. In fact, it might help if I table the draft form. It is an application entitled `Private health insurance incentive scheme: eligibility questionnaire and application'. Perhaps in comparison with that, I could table the income and assets review form put out by the Department of Social Security.
—I appreciate that very much, thank you. As I understand it, that document that was supposed to be 15 pages is now less than that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it is. I think you will find it is about eight pages, but five of them require filling in.
—Is that still a draft document, or is it the final document?
—It is a draft document.
—When might we have the final one?

—That is being attended to. I cannot give you a time, Senator Crowley, but I will make inquiries and get back to you. We do not intend making the document more voluminous than it is. In fact, if it can be shortened, I think it would be desirable. But certainly there is no intention to make it any longer than it is at the moment, and it is certainly not 15 pages long.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the requests (Senator Neal's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator Bob Collins did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza.)

Some opinions say five per cent and others say it should be a six per cent increase. We are putting it at only a three per cent increase and we are saying that if by the year 2000 this has not succeeded—in other words, if $1.7 billion has basically gone down the drain—we should pull the plug on it and we will have learned the lesson. We should then at least put this whole issue back before this chamber and not continue with something which has not been successful.

The parliamentary secretary said, I think, that $1.7 billion is a bandaid as far as the public system is concerned and it would not last very much time at all. With due respect, I say to him that, say, $500 million a year could make an enormous difference to our public system. To begin with, if we had a spare $100 million to put into our public hospitals, we could look at some active intervention to reduce waiting times; at a capital works program for some of our older hospitals; at a technology acquisition program; and at some difficulties the hospitals are having with administration thanks to the new casemix system. One hundred million dollars a year would put our dental services back in place. One hundred million dollars into Aboriginal health, directed through community health services, would make an enormous difference. In rural health, the minimum suggested if we really are serious about providing rural Australians with adequate health is about $60 million for community and health support services in rural Australia.

As for mental health, my home state, South Australia, for example, is basically divided in two for child and adolescent mental health services. Just to give you an example of how far money has to stretch, the northern half—everything north of Adelaide and out to the west as far as the West Australian border—is running on a budget of $300,000 a year. As I think I said in this place yesterday when I was looking at the mental health issue, young people in Whyalla who are assessed as in urgent need of support and help have a 14‐month wait, even if they are suicidal.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I want to refer to an article, which was in the Sydney Sun‐Herald on Sunday, 2 March, under the heading `Blainey attacks Mabo case judges'. That article refers both to the comments of Professor Geoffrey Blainey in his address to the Sir Arthur Fadden memorial dinner last Friday night in Townsville and to comments by the Queensland Premier, Mr Rob Borbidge, who has referred to comments made in that speech. It is incredible that Professor Blainey, if the article correctly reports him, is prepared to make comments which seem to me to trivialise the history of Australia and particularly the history of the Aboriginal population in Australia. The article says:

SPEECH.PARA: In a stinging attack on the High Court, Professor Blainey told the inaugural Sir Arthur Fadden Memorial Dinner at Townsville on Friday night that Sir William—
referring to Sir William Deane—
and another High Court judge, whom he did not name, had deplorably misused history to back their decisions on Mabo legislation.
He said the judges had turned political and accused whites of the wholesale massacre of Aborigines when most had died of diseases inadvertently spread by Europeans.

In relation to that, Professor Geoffrey Blainey and a number of other historians have published their views on Australian history. I have taken the opportunity to look at some of those views, particularly with regard to the history of the decline in the Aboriginal population.

For the greater part of the 19th century, a reduction from approximately 300,000 to about 50,000 occurred and nowhere in the history can it be said that that reduction—in terms of the numbers, from 300,000 to 50,000—was due to the massacre or the direct killing of the Aboriginal population by the new settlers. In fact, figures of between 10,000 and 20,000 have been put forward as reasonable guesstimates of the number of Aboriginals who were killed in skirmishes, either official or unofficial, between settlers or between organised military activities on behalf of the colonists. So there was obviously a decline in the population of about 250,000, and less than 10 per cent of that was due to the direct killing of the population by the settlers in organised or disorganised fashions.

In the publication The Other Side of the Frontier by Professor Henry Reynolds there is reference not only to the issue of the disease which had an impact upon the population but also to the issue of the fall in the birthrate in that population. I want to refer to that passage from that work because it is very unfortunate that we have a debate in the community at the moment which is very superficial and which is not really addressing the issues of the cause of the decline in the population. We will not address this in a manner which will be illuminating to the Australian population if we rely upon articles such as the one published last Sunday that I am referring to. Professor Reynolds said:

The catastrophic fall in the birth rate was another factor of demographic significance. Aborigines not only died at unprecedented rates; they were not born, or did not survive childhood, in anything like sufficient numbers to replace the loss by premature death. `A child is now but rarely to be met with', wrote a white official in melancholy mood, `a birth but seldom known'. The missionary Benjamin Hurst commented in 1841 that he knew of only two children under twelve within a forty mile radius of his station on the western side of Port Phillip Bay. A settler at Lake Colac noted that amongst one hundred or so local women there had been no more than six or eight children born in the previous three years. A contemporary could recall only two births in five years in his district and both children later died. William Thomas kept detailed records of the Port Phillip and Western Port clans. Between 1848 and 1858 the population fell from 92 to 56 and only one child survived. The story was similar all over the continent. In district after district children were found to be `few beyond all proportion'. Many of the factors—malnutrition, exposure, disease and especially V.D. in a variety of forms—were only too apparent. But beyond even their lethal reach there was the loss of land, the dislocation of the known universe, a previous unthinkable disruption of the cosmic cycle of birth and death and reincarnation. Some groups exhibited an unquenchable determination to survive; for others the onslaught of invasion had destroyed everything. The future itself had been extinguished. Death from disease and chronic infant mortality merely proved that the times were irrecoverably out of joint. The Port Phillip Protectors reported Aboriginal comments eloquent with despair, leached of all hope. Thomas referred to `this indifference to prolong their race, on the ground as they state of having no country they can call their own'. `No country, no good have it pickaninnys', one Aborigine explained, while another lamented `no country now for them . . . and no more come up pickaninny'.

So, in the middle of the last century, the issue of land as related to the survival of Aborigines was one which had been noted by the then historians. Referring back to the reported comments of Geoffrey Blainey, it would be more appropriate if, rather than relying upon a recitation of history which suits slogans such as `Black armband history', Professor Blainey were more responsible and had more regard to the real history of this country.

I must say that, when I grew up in the 1950s, we were not taught at school about the real history of Australia. I think that is a comment which applies to most of the Australians who grew up in the early postwar period. I think it is not surprising that there are a lot of people out there who have not been made aware of the real history; people to whom the prejudiced logic—in my view—of some of the opponents of Aboriginal land rights has an appeal.
Later in the article there is a quote from the Queensland Premier, Mr Borbidge, which makes reference to Professor Blainey's address at the Sir Arthur Fadden memorial dinner. It says:
The concept of land tenure based on race is racist. The High Court has made itself political. Mr Blainey's speech went to the heart of the dilemma facing this country over the Wik decision.

Indeed, that is consistent with what is reported to have been Professor Blainey's attack on the Mabo decision and the native title legislation. But I think that is quite an unfair assertion. The basis of the Mabo decision and the native title legislation which followed it is that there must have been long‐term occupancy. Most European land tenure has a lot to do with long‐term occupancy; it is nothing to do with race. But, in the case of Eddie Mabo and in the case of the native title legislation, the long‐term occupants were Aboriginal, so it is unremarkable that their right to title relates to their race. There were no other occupants here prior to European settlement. It is an irrelevancy.

The concept is not based on race; it is, in fact, based on long‐term occupancy of this country, just as most European land title is based on long‐term occupancy. It would be equally flawed to say that the French, the English or the German land tenure systems were based upon race. They are equally based on long‐term occupancy. I would suggest that Premier Borbidge and Professor Blainey have a good close look at the logic of their statements before they make such inflammatory statements to the Australian population.
