TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 12 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How does the Government determine the regulations under which the sale of alcohol or gambling may occur on Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) land.
(2) Is a licensed facility on FAC land at Parafield Airport subject to the same operating regulations and restrictions, as other South Australian licensed facilities; if not, why not.
(3) Should licensed premises at Parafield Airport be allowed to open without regard for the restrictions that apply on Christmas Day or Good Friday, under State law.

(4) Can the Federal Government guarantee that community standards will be upheld, and that no retailer can undermine the reasonable restrictions that are placed on licensed premises, under the laws of South Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Transport and Regional Development

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The FAC operates under the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986 which allows the FAC to make by‐laws not inconsistent with the Act or the regulations, for liquor and gambling (under s72(1)(p) and (q)). The Act also has provision for the Governor‐General to make regulations not inconsistent with the Act (s74).

PARA.TAB: The FAC has further advised that, in keeping with the FAC Act, the Corporation endeavours to perform its functions in a manner that is consistent with that allowed under the laws of the relevant States or Territories it operates within.

ANSWER.PARA: (2) In the case of the new FAC tavern on Parafield Airport which commenced trading on 1 December 1996, the FAC liaised and consulted at length with the SA Government to satisfy all concerned that the spirit of SA liquor and gaming laws was reflected in the FAC agreement with the tavern operator. The State Government agreed with the final position. In fact, the SA Gaming Law was changed after the agreement was put in place (in the tavern lease and authority documents) and before the tavern opened (amendment effective from 1 July 1996) so the FAC entered into a deed of variation with its tenant to directly reflect these changes.

There is provision in the FAC agreement to vary it further if necessary . . . having regard to prevailing community attitudes from time to time or amendments to the hours during which similar businesses in South Australia are entitled to trade or any other matters which the Corporation reasonably considers relevant.

The FAC has also written into its agreement with the operator, provisions for State Gaming Inspectors to have the same powers (under Section 71 of the SA Gaming Machines Act 1992) as they have in other similar facilities.

(3) The FAC does not believe that the Parafield Airport licensed facilities should open without similar restrictions on Christmas Day or Good Friday and the SA law is reflected in the FAC agreement. In SA, gaming is not allowed on Christmas Day, but taverns and hotels may trade between restricted hours, and accordingly the tavern at Parafield was opened on Christmas Day 1996. SA law currently prohibits the sale and supply of liquor and gaming operations on Good Friday and the same applies at the airport tavern.

(4) The FAC believes that the administration of licensed premises on Parafield Airport does not allow the undermining of reasonable restrictions that are placed on licensed premises, under the laws of South Australia. As stated in the answer to (2) above, there is specific provision for regard to prevailing community attitudes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 6 January 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Given the long‐running conflict in Sudan which has resulted in the loss of hundreds of thousands of lives, the recent escape of the Opposition leader, meetings of church representatives from both sides of the conflict and the recent change in United States policy in providing assistance towards opponents of the Sudanese regime:
(1) What is the Australian Government's position on the conflict in Sudan.
(2) Does the Australian Government support: (a) current United States sanctions against flights between the United States and Sudan; and (b) bans on Sudanese official government visits.
(3) Will the Australian Government bring in the same sanctions and bans as the United States.
(4) Will the Australian Government bring in any further sanctions or bans against the Sudanese regime.
(5) What diplomatic action will the Australian Government take against the Sudanese regime.
(6) Will the Australian Government sponsor or support any resolutions to the United Nations on the situation in Sudan.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australia Government supports international and regional efforts to bring the conflict in Sudan to an end. We hope Sudan will join with other regional parties in finding lasting solutions to the region's social, political and economic problems. Both the UN and Australia have urged the Government of Sudan to commit itself to participate in negotiations sponsored by the Inter‐Governmental Authority on Development (IGAD). Only a multilateral solution such as proposed by the IGAD is likely to end the war. It is disappointing that peace negotiations mediated by the IGAD have so far made little tangible process. The IGAD forum, nevertheless, has the potential to be an effective avenue for the promotion and coordination of regional peace and stability, and for the realisation of sustainable economic and social development. For the IGAD to be successful in bringing peace to Sudan, there must be greater involvement and commitment on the part of all IGAD members.

(2) There are no flights operating between the United States and Sudan and no sanctions at this stage on flights between the two countries. United Nations Security Council Resolution (UNSCR) 1070 of 16 August 1996 calls on States to deny aircraft permission to take off from, land in, or overfly their territories if the aircraft is registered in Sudan, or owned, leased or operated by or on behalf of Sudan Airways, or by or on behalf of the Government or public authorities of Sudan. The date for the implementation of this air embargo is yet to be determined by the Security Council.

The Australian Government has imposed entry and transit restrictions on members and officials of the Sudanese Government and Sudanese armed forces personnel as required by UNSCR 1054. UNSCR 1054 requires all States to: (a) significantly reduce the number and the level of the staff at Sudanese diplomatic missions and consular posts and restrict or control the movement within their territory of all such staff who remain; and (b) take steps to restrict the entry into or transit through their territory of members of the Government of Sudan, officials of the Government and members of the armed forces. There are no Sudanese diplomatic or consular posts in Australia.

The sanctions set out in UNSCR 1054 arose out of Sudan's failure to fulfil the undertakings of UNSCR 1044 which demands the extradition of three suspects in connection with the attempted assassination of Egyptian President Mubarak and that Sudan cease activities which support terrorism.
(3) As members of the United Nations, Australia and the United States are implementing relevant Security Council resolutions relevant to Sudan.
(4) The Australian Government will move to impose the air embargo contained in UNSCR 1070 when, and if, an implementation date is agreed by the Security Council.

(5) The Government continues to support international and regional efforts to bring the civil war in Sudan to an end and considers the best avenue for achieving peace in Sudan to be through the Inter‐Governmental Authority on Development (IGAD). The IGAD forum is probably the most promising avenue for the promotion of regional peace and stability, and for the realisation of sustainable economic and social development.

The Australian Government is also concerned about repeated allegations of human rights abuses in Sudan. Our views regarding such abuses are conveyed to the Government of Sudan through bilateral channels, as well as multilateral forums. Our Ambassador in Cairo, who is accredited to Khartoum, makes bilateral representations to the Sudanese Government on individual cases as well as the human rights situation in general.

(6) Australia continues to speak out about the human rights situation in Sudan in the UN General Assembly and the UN Commission on Human Rights. The Australian Government has actively supported efforts by the UN to monitor the situation in Sudan and to apply pressure on the Government of Sudan to abide by its human rights obligations. Australia co‐sponsored resolutions on Sudan at the 52nd session of the UN Commission on Human Rights and the 51st session of the UN General Assembly. The resolutions expressed deep concern at reports of religious persecution and slavery in Sudan and urged greater cooperation by the Sudanese Government with the UN Special Rapporteur on human rights in Sudan, with international agencies, humanitarian organisations and donor governments. The resolutions also call on the Government of Sudan to cease immediately all attacks that are in violation of international humanitarian law and to abide by international human rights instruments to which Sudan is a party.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 January 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the shipment of 40 canisters of reprocessed nuclear waste which will be travelling from France through the South Pacific and the Tasman Sea on the Pacific Teal:

(1) (a) What is the proposed route of the Pacific Teal; (b) what is the timing of the proposed route; (c) between what dates will the Pacific Teal be: (i) in the vicinity of Australia, and (ii) in the vicinity of Australia and New Zealand; (d) will the ship enter Australia's exclusive economic zone; and (e) what is the closest distance to Australia that the ship will come to.
(2) What scheduled port visits or possible port visits are in that route.
(3) What is the composition of the nuclear waste.

(4) Has the Government conducted a full investigation as to the safety risks and emergency procedures involved with accidents or leaks of the waste in the vicinity of Australia; if so, please provide details of the investigation; if not, why not.

(5) Does the Australian Government share the view of the New Zealand Government that the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) safety standards have been adhered to, but they should be strengthened; if not, why not.

(6) With reference to statements by the New Zealand Government that it is making efforts to have those IAEA standards raised but is not confident of success: (a) what needs to happen in order for these standards to be raised; (b) will Australia support the efforts of New Zealand to have these standards raised; and (c) does Australia support the principle of improving the IAEA standards governing the transport of nuclear waste; if so, what is the Australian Government doing about this.
(7) (a) Which countries have come out against the waste shipments; and (b) does Australia disagree with the positions taken by these countries: if so, on what basis.

(8) (a) What is Australia's position on the waste shipments; (b) could the Government legally oppose waste shipments from Japan; and (c) is the Government compromised in its position on waste shipments due to the contracts, bilateral agreements and approvals associated with selling uranium to Japan.
(9) (a) Is there any Australian uranium in the reprocessed waste to Japan; and (b) can the Government guarantee that there is no Australian uranium in the reprocessed waste shipment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The Government has been advised that the general route of the Pacific Teal will be around the Cape of Good Hope, then south of Australia and through the Southwest Pacific to Japan. The exact route will be determined by the ship's captain.
(b) The Pacific Teal left Cherbourg, France on 13 January 1997. It is expected to arrive in Japan in mid‐March.
(c) (i) The ship is expected to be in Australia's vicinity throughout the second half of February.
(ii) As for (1)(c)(i) above.
(d) This is a matter for the ship's captain to determine, in accordance with the right of freedom of navigation under international law.

(e) As the exact route of the shipment will be determined by the ship's captain, it is not possible to provide an answer to this question, beyond stating that the Australian Government has been given assurances by the Japanese, French and British Governments that the planned route of the Pacific Teal will not entail passage through Australia's territorial waters.
(2) The Government has been advised that no port visits are scheduled during the voyage.

(3) The waste being carried by the Pacific Teal is high‐level radioactive waste (HLW), consisting of mixed fission products resulting from the reprocessing of spent nuclear fuel. The waste is in a vitrified form which, along with the highly engineered packaging, ensures a high degree of retention of the radioactive contents even in the worst accident conditions. The waste contains no recoverable plutonium or uranium.

(4) No specific investigation has been carried out in relation to the current shipment. As noted in the answer to question (8)(a) below, the Australian Government has received assurances from the Japanese, French and British Governments, which together are responsible for the shipment, that the shipment is in accordance with the relevant international standards. Appropriate arrangements, involving a number of Government Departments and Agencies including the Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre, are in place to coordinate an Australian response to maritime emergencies, including any emergency involving the Pacific Teal in Australia's area of responsibility for maritime search and rescue. Such arrangements would be activated promptly if an emergency arose.

(5) The Australian Government has no reason to believe that the current shipment does not conform to the safety standards prescribed in the International Atomic Energy Agency's (IAEA) Regulations for the Safe Transport of Nuclear Material. In that regard, the New Zealand Government has not questioned the adequacy of the regulations: its concerns in relation to the standards for the transportation of radioactive waste by sea relate primarily to two areas—the International Maritime Organisation's Irradiated Nuclear Fuels Code (the INF Code, which draws on and is complementary to the IAEA regulations), and civil liability for nuclear damage. In the case of the INF Code, New Zealand has called for greater transparency and consultation with coastal states on routes, and for the code to be made mandatory. Australia supports calls for transparency and consultation, within the limits of safety and security, and is satisfied with efforts made by Japan, France and the UK in relation to the current shipment. Australia has also supported, in principle, calls for the INF Code to be made mandatory, although the full implications of this proposal are still being examined. On liability, New Zealand and Australia are contributing to the work of the IAEA's Standing Committee on Nuclear Liability, to establish a world‐wide liability regime to supplement and enhance the measures in the Vienna and Paris Conventions, as well as in relevant national legislation, on compensation for nuclear damage, with a view to increasing the amount of compensation for nuclear damage, including transboundary damage.
(6) (a) As noted in the answer to question (5) above, the New Zealand Government has not put forward any proposals in relation to the IAEA's Regulations for the Safe Transport of Nuclear Material.
(b) See (6)(a) above.

(c) The IAEA's Regulations for the Safe Transport of Nuclear Material have been in existence since 1961 and have been regularly reviewed and revised. Australia supports efforts to refine the regulations, and is active in the IAEA Transport Safety Standards Advisory Committee, which is charged with producing and updating IAEA transport standards and regulations.

(7) (a) Reports have come to our notice that a number of countries have expressed varying degrees of concern about the current shipment. In our region these include the Cook Islands, Fiji, Malaysia, New Zealand and Vanuatu. The South Pacific Forum Secretariat has reiterated the Forum's concern over the shipment of high‐level nuclear and other hazardous wastes through the South Pacific Region. Malaysia, New Zealand and Vanuatu have each sought assurances on the possible passage of the Pacific Teal through their exclusive economic zones, as has Mauritius in the Indian Ocean. Several countries in Latin America also expressed concern about the shipment when it was thought possible that the ship would travel via Cape Horn or the Panama Canal.

(b) The Australian Government believes it is important that the shipment be made in accordance with the appropriate, internationally‐accepted safety standards. The Government accepts the right of freedom of navigation through the exclusive economic zones of states, in accordance with the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea.

(8) (a) The Australian Government has made numerous representations to ensure that arrangements for the shipment of radioactive waste, as with any hazardous waste, meet acceptable standards. Australia has consistently joined with other South Pacific Forum countries in expressing concern that shipments of radioactive waste through our region be made in accordance with the highest international safety and security standards, in a manner which satisfactorily addresses all possible contingencies, and in full consultation with Forum countries.

Australian authorities, including the Nuclear Safety Bureau (NSB) and the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) have confidence in the International Atomic Energy Agency's Regulations for the Safe Transport of Nuclear Material, which are internationally agreed and regularly revised. Australia has received assurances from the Japanese, French and British Governments that the current shipment is in accordance with these standards and indeed in some respects exceeds them. The Government is therefore satisfied that the radiological protection and safety arrangements for shipments to Japan meet or exceed all of the relevant international standards, and that the shipments do not pose any serious health or environmental threat.

Australia accepts that international law grants states a right of freedom of navigation of their ships on the high seas or through states' exclusive economic zones, and the right of innocent passage through the territorial sea of coastal states. We also accept Japan's right to make sovereign choices about its energy mix, just as Australia expects to be left to decide how to meet its own power generation requirements. The transport by sea of HLW is a function of the industrial and contractual arrangements established under Japan's nuclear power program; it is also consistent with the widely‐accepted principle that countries look after their own waste material.

(b) The Government would not have grounds for legally opposing the shipment of HLW to Japan. The United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, to which Australia is party, grants states a right of freedom of navigation for their ships on the high seas or through other states' exclusive economic zones. The Convention also grants states the right of innocent passage through the territorial sea of coastal states, with ships carrying nuclear material being allowed passage provided they "carry documents and observe special precautionary measures established for such ships by international agreements".
(c) No.

(9) (a) The HLW contains no nuclear material which, in the terminology of our bilateral safeguards agreements, is Australian‐obligated nuclear material (AONM). This is because safeguards are terminated on HLW when it is processed into a form where the minute amounts of remnant nuclear material it contains are no longer practically recoverable. Our various bilateral agreements provide that bilateral safeguards terminate when IAEA safeguards terminate. Thus the HLW contains no nuclear material which is any longer subject to bilateral safeguards or identifiable by national safeguards obligation. Since, however, the waste material is derived from the reprocessing of spent fuel comprised in part of AONM, it can be assumed to contain minute amounts of remnant material similarly derived, although not recognizably Australian. Since this remnant material is no longer of safeguards interest there is no requirement for it to be the subject of further safeguards accounting under our bilateral safeguards agreements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 3 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Does participation in a labour market program count as `recent workforce experience' when determining a person's eligibility for the Widow Allowance; for example, would a woman who had undertaken a Jobskills placement need to wait a further 12 months from the completion of that before becoming eligible for the Widow Allowance; if so, to which labour market programs does this apply?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Labour market programmes that attract a wage are considered to be employment. These programmes comprise Jobskills, Jobstart and the New Enterprise Incentive Scheme (NEIS). Participation in an employment based labour market programme would count as `recent workforce experience' when determining a person's eligibility for Widow Allowance. Other labour market programs such as Jobtrain, New Work Opportunities and Special Employer Support are considered to be training rather than employment, and would not count as `recent workforce experience'.

A woman who is not eligible for Widow Allowance because she has `recent workforce experience' would need to claim Newstart Allowance. If the woman is unsuccessful at finding further employment after 9 months in receipt of Newstart Allowance, she may then qualify for Widow Allowance.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 3 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Has a departmental review of the impact of the phasing out of the Widow B Pension recently been completed; if so, what were the findings and recommendations of that review.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The evaluation of the phasing out of Widow B Pension and the introduction of Widow Allowance has not yet been completed.
There are three phases to the evaluation: (1) qualitative research through focus groups, (2) quantitative research through face‐to‐face surveys and (3) in‐depth analysis of data.

The first phase has been completed. The third phase will be finalised once surveying is finished.
